tags: justice for elia and her children
summary: Can we all just take another moments to remember that fans of R&L say that Rhaegar chose Lyanna cuz she was more attractive than...
body: Can we all just take another moments to remember that fans of R&L say that Rhaegar chose Lyanna cuz she was more attractive than Elia? When it’s quoted In “The World of Ice and Fire”, Maester Yandel compares Lyanna to Elia, stating the she-wolf was “a wild and boyish young thing with none of the Princess Elia’s delicate beauty” so 🤔 I want to believe that Rhaegar was fond and cared enough for Elia that he didn’t want to lose her in childbirth. He chose Lyanna because he wanted his Visenya to be fierce, which I guess she was. I know we won’t get justice for Elia in season 8, because D&D want the focus to be on a love story that’s flawed. They stole Elia’s sons name and have it to Jon Snow, I refuse to believe that’s the way the books will go. Because George RR Martin has said that the relationship between Elia and Rhaegar was complicated, and Rhaegar was to sad to truly love anyone. So I don’t think he loved either Lyanna or Elia, just himself as per usual.

blog.name: alle23212
blog.title: Alle.
blog.description:
librisognierealta.it è il mio blog.
Ho sempre sentito il bisogno di averne uno, ma non avevo mai trovato un argomento che mi spingesse a continuare a scrivere, finché non ho abbracciato la mia natura ossessia-compulsiva e assolutamente pignola! Da questo è nato il mio blog di recensioni e scleri di vario genere: Libri, Sogni e Realtà.

summary: Hi! I’ve been a fan of Game of Thrones and A Song of Ice and Fire for so long, but I don’t have any mutuals that post or reblog...
body:
Hi! I’ve been a fan of Game of Thrones and A Song of Ice and Fire for so long, but I don’t have any mutuals that post or reblog about it. Can you please like and reblog this post, so we can become mutuals? 

I particulary love these characters (Sansa, Margaery, Cersei and Theon are my favorite characters out of everyone else):

  • Sansa Stark
  • Jeyne Poole
  • Theon Greyjoy
  • Viserys Targaryen
  • Rhaella Targaryen
  • Rhaegar Targaryen
  • Lyanna Stark
  • Cersei Lannister
  • Jaime Lannister
  • Tywin Lannister
  • Myrcella Baratheon
  • Trystane Martell
  • Elia Martell
  • Oberyn Martell
  • Brienne Of Tarth
  • Sandor Clegane
  • Olenna Tyrell
  • Margaery Tyrell
  • Loras Tyrell
  • Eddard Stark
  • Catelyn Stark
  • Bran Stark
  • Jojen Reed
  • Grey Worm
  • Missandei
  • Jon Snow
  • Varys
  • Shae

Thank you!

summary: Reigns Is Coming to Game of Thrones, and the Rest of This Week in Games
title: Reigns Is Coming to Game of Thrones, and the Rest of This Week in Games
body:
It’s the end of summer, which means things are quiet, but not that quiet. This week, we’ve got Xbox rentals, the ongoing problem of sexy games on Steam, and some card-swiping royalty gameplay in the Game of Thrones universe. 🎶 Come with me, and you’ll be in a world of pure gamification …. 🎶

We’ve Got More Details on Microsoft’s Xbox Subscription Service

Like everyone in the games industry, Microsoft has been working to figure out most successful ways to distribute their games and systems to the masses. Does the traditional model still work in 2018? Or is there a better way? Game streaming is one option a lot of people have tried, or are interested in—Microsoft included—but a recent report by The Verge suggests they’re opting for another route, too: console subscriptions.

Remember when you could rent, like, a whole Dreamcast from Blockbuster for a week? It seems like it’ll work like that: according to early sources, the subscription from Microsoft Stores will include an Xbox One (either the S or the fancy X version), Xbox Live Gold, and the Xbox Game Pass, which offers various games for download on a subscription basis, for $34.99 a month. It’s an interesting deal, though I’m not sure how many people want to go to a physical location to rent a console. Still, alternatives to the current method—i.e., buying another big videogame-running brick every five years—are always welcome.

The Situation for Sexy Steam Games is Supremely Sticky

Steam’s problems with content regulation are old hat to anyone who is familiar with games by now, but this story still is pretty jarring: with a new content moderation system in progress, Steam has seemingly halted the approval process for some adult games until the new system is finished. According to a report by Kotaku, several developers have found themselves stuck in release purgatory for months, with no clear answers and no end in sight.

It’s understandable for Steam to not want certain content on its platform—that’s its prerogative. But withholding both approval and clarity from developers isn’t particularly good for anyone.

The Mobile Hit Reigns is Coming to Westeros

Reigns is an immensely clever game, a mash-up of the mind-numbing minutiae of ruling a kingdom with the mind-numbing habit of swiping right or left to run your dating life. Sassy and artistic, Reigns and its sequel have been a mobile smash hit;—and now their creators, alongside publisher Devolver Digital, have done the natural thing, and teamed up with the folks who made Game of Thrones. Introducing, uh, Reigns: Game of Thrones, due out in October in Android, iOS, and PC.

When it comes out, you’ll be able to take on the roles of various royal types from the universe, beginning as Daenerys and unlocking more as you go along, die, and try again. Can you get to the Iron Throne? Or at least survive the winter? I probably can’t; I’m terrible at these sorts of games.

Recommendation of the Week: Shenmue 1 & 2

In this current age of the remaster, this is no doubt one of the big ones. The Shenmue games, first released for the Dreamcast in 1999 and 2001, respectively, were epochal in so many ways. Their DNA is all over modern-day open-world games, slice-of-life role-playing games, and the entire genre of modern, peaceful indies. A fascinating soap operatic story of seeking a father’s killer mixed with bits of brawling, romance, and regular life simulation make Shenmue and its sequel two of the most distinct, and fondly remembered, games of their time. Now, they’re on modern consoles and PC. Check ‘em out.

More Great WIRED Stories

  • How NotPetya, a single piece of code, crashed the world
  • Elon Musk has a plan to save LA Dodger fans from traffic
  • Wildfire smoke kills—even where you don’t expect it
  • PHOTO ESSAY: The techies of Kenya’s Silicon Savannah
  • The strange David and Goliath saga of radio frequencies
  • Get even more of our inside scoops with our weekly Backchannel newsletter

Related Video

Gaming
Riot Games’ Greg Street Answers League of Legends Questions from Twitter

Riot Games Lead Designer Greg Street uses the power of Twitter to answer some common questions about League of Legends. When will teemo get deleted? Why is it taking so long to release another permanent game mode? Why are death timers so long in one for all? Why does the entire team get punished when one player rage quits? How long until a Battle Royale game mode is announced? When is LoL 2 coming?

Read more: https://www.wired.com/story/replay-game-news-reigns/

The post <em>Reigns</em> Is Coming to <em>Game of Thrones</em>, and the Rest of This Week in Games appeared first on Viral TV News.



from WordPress http://www.viraltvnews.com/game_of_thrones/reigns-is-coming-to-game-of-thrones-and-the-rest-of-this-week-in-games/

Steam’s problems with content regulation are old hat to anyone who is familiar with games by now, but this story still is pretty jarring: with a new content moderation system in progress, Steam has seemingly halted the approval process for some adult games until the new system is finished. According to a report by Kotaku, several developers have found themselves stuck in release purgatory for months, with no clear answers and no end in sight.

It’s understandable for Steam to not want certain content on its platform—that’s its prerogative. But withholding both approval and clarity from developers isn’t particularly good for anyone.

The Mobile Hit Reigns is Coming to Westeros

Reigns is an immensely clever game, a mash-up of the mind-numbing minutiae of ruling a kingdom with the mind-numbing habit of swiping right or left to run your dating life. Sassy and artistic, Reigns and its sequel have been a mobile smash hit;—and now their creators, alongside publisher Devolver Digital, have done the natural thing, and teamed up with the folks who made Game of Thrones. Introducing, uh, Reigns: Game of Thrones, due out in October in Android, iOS, and PC.

When it comes out, you’ll be able to take on the roles of various royal types from the universe, beginning as Daenerys and unlocking more as you go along, die, and try again. Can you get to the Iron Throne? Or at least survive the winter? I probably can’t; I’m terrible at these sorts of games.

Recommendation of the Week: Shenmue 1 & 2

In this current age of the remaster, this is no doubt one of the big ones. The Shenmue games, first released for the Dreamcast in 1999 and 2001, respectively, were epochal in so many ways. Their DNA is all over modern-day open-world games, slice-of-life role-playing games, and the entire genre of modern, peaceful indies. A fascinating soap operatic story of seeking a father’s killer mixed with bits of brawling, romance, and regular life simulation make Shenmue and its sequel two of the most distinct, and fondly remembered, games of their time. Now, they’re on modern consoles and PC. Check ‘em out.

Gaming
Riot Games’ Greg Street Answers League of Legends Questions from Twitter

Riot Games Lead Designer Greg Street uses the power of Twitter to answer some common questions about League of Legends. When will teemo get deleted? Why is it taking so long to release another permanent game mode? Why are death timers so long in one for all? Why does the entire team get punished when one player rage quits? How long until a Battle Royale game mode is announced? When is LoL 2 coming?

Read more: https://www.wired.com/story/replay-game-news-reigns/

The post <em>Reigns</em> Is Coming to <em>Game of Thrones</em>, and the Rest of This Week in Games appeared first on Viral TV News.



from WordPress http://www.viraltvnews.com/game_of_thrones/reigns-is-coming-to-game-of-thrones-and-the-rest-of-this-week-in-games/
trail.content:
It’s the end of summer, which means things are quiet, but not that quiet. This week, we’ve got Xbox rentals, the ongoing problem of sexy games on Steam, and some card-swiping royalty gameplay in the Game of Thrones universe. 🎶 Come with me, and you’ll be in a world of pure gamification …. 🎶

We’ve Got More Details on Microsoft’s Xbox Subscription Service

Like everyone in the games industry, Microsoft has been working to figure out most successful ways to distribute their games and systems to the masses. Does the traditional model still work in 2018? Or is there a better way? Game streaming is one option a lot of people have tried, or are interested in—Microsoft included—but a recent report by The Verge suggests they’re opting for another route, too: console subscriptions.

Remember when you could rent, like, a whole Dreamcast from Blockbuster for a week? It seems like it’ll work like that: according to early sources, the subscription from Microsoft Stores will include an Xbox One (either the S or the fancy X version), Xbox Live Gold, and the Xbox Game Pass, which offers various games for download on a subscription basis, for $34.99 a month. It’s an interesting deal, though I’m not sure how many people want to go to a physical location to rent a console. Still, alternatives to the current method—i.e., buying another big videogame-running brick every five years—are always welcome.

The Situation for Sexy Steam Games is Supremely Sticky

Steam’s problems with content regulation are old hat to anyone who is familiar with games by now, but this story still is pretty jarring: with a new content moderation system in progress, Steam has seemingly halted the approval process for some adult games until the new system is finished. According to a report by Kotaku, several developers have found themselves stuck in release purgatory for months, with no clear answers and no end in sight.

It’s understandable for Steam to not want certain content on its platform—that’s its prerogative. But withholding both approval and clarity from developers isn’t particularly good for anyone.

Reigns is an immensely clever game, a mash-up of the mind-numbing minutiae of ruling a kingdom with the mind-numbing habit of swiping right or left to run your dating life. Sassy and artistic, Reigns and its sequel have been a mobile smash hit;—and now their creators, alongside publisher Devolver Digital, have done the natural thing, and teamed up with the folks who made Game of Thrones. Introducing, uh, Reigns: Game of Thrones, due out in October in Android, iOS, and PC.

When it comes out, you’ll be able to take on the roles of various royal types from the universe, beginning as Daenerys and unlocking more as you go along, die, and try again. Can you get to the Iron Throne? Or at least survive the winter? I probably can’t; I’m terrible at these sorts of games.

Their DNA is all over modern-day open-world games, slice-of-life role-playing games, and the entire genre of modern, peaceful indies. A fascinating soap operatic story of seeking a father’s killer mixed with bits of brawling, romance, and regular life simulation make Shenmue and its sequel two of the most distinct, and fondly remembered, games of their time. Now, they’re on modern consoles and PC. Check ‘em out.

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: Happy birthday George R. R. Martin!
title: Happy birthday George R. R. Martin!
excerpt: The writer George R. R. Martin turns 70
description:
George Raymond Martin, this is his birth name, was born on September 20, 1948 in Bayonne, New Jersey, USA. Years later he added the name Richard after chosing it as his confirmation name.

Ever since he was a child, George R. R. Martin showed his desire to write stories and in those years he read a lot of science fiction, fantasy and horror from previous years, becoming fan of Marvel comics. Through the readers letters published in the comics, he came into contact with the fandom and various fanzines, where he published a number of stories.

After years spent working mainly on television, also with various projects that were not successful, George R. R. Martin got tired, also for the limits imposed by budget and the rigid length of television episodes. In the early 1990s he started writing a fantasy saga that was originally a trilogy but was later expanded to better develop the story: in 1996 he published “A Game of Thrones”, the first novel of the saga that enormously increased the author’s fame.
